newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Aeroflot pens deal to buy "Russian-American" jets.
newsitem.headline: Aeroflot pens deal to buy "Russian-American" jets.

text.p: Russia's Aeroflot airline Tuesday signed a $1.5 billion deal to buy 20 Russian jets equipped with American engines and electronics, a move officials hope will help revive the faltering domestic aviation sector.
Under the agreement, the Voronezh Jet Construction company will build the IL-96 M/T planes and equip them with Pratt & Whitney engines and electronics made by Rockwell Avionics.
The new jets are part of an expansion by Aeroflot, which inherited the foreign routes of the once Soviet airline and is now seeking to modernise its ageing fleet.
Aeroflot already operates several Western jets, and has announced plans to purchase 10 Boeing jets.
"The IL-96-300s we fly today have proved not bad, but we need even better quality," said Yevgeny Shaposhnikov, Aeroflot's general director.
"The new technology is represented by the IL-96 M/T. I'm a patriot, but I'm also fighting for quality, reliability, regularity and safety, which prompted me to sign this contract," Shaposhnikov said.

The Russian aviation industry has complained that Aeroflot's growing use of Western aircraft is crippling domestic aircraft production. Aeroflot officials said aiding domestic production was also a factor in signing the deal.
Shaposhnikov, who was the last defence minister of the Soviet Union, said Aerosflot's main long-distance jet will be the IL-96, short flights will be on Boeing 737s.
Alexei Bochkarev, programme manager for Rockwell's Russian operations, said the contract for adapting American aviation electronics for Russian planes was worth roughly $50 million.
Officials said the American components in the new planes -- the engines and aviation electronics -- are worth a little more than half of the plane's entire cost.
Aeroflot expects to start flying the new plane in the second half of 1997, pending certification.
